49.text:
- Hello, and welcome to     
    Compass, a production

53.text:
I'm Les Heen, your       
       host for Compass.

55.text:
This is a weekly              
  discussion of public policy

57.text:
and important issues        
    facing our viewing area.

59.text:
This week we will look at       
what's new in the dairy industry

64.text:
We'll see how farmers are    
   keeping up with demands

67.text:
And working through what could 
 be some challenging times.

70.text:
First we have the story      
   of how a family dairy farm

73.text:
near Chokio, Minnesota moved  
  into the automated side

77.text:
For a closer look at       
     how that farm has seen

81.text:
here's a report from      
      Laura Kay Prosser.

85.text:
- The Blackwelders have       
  been farming their homestead

90.text:
But it wasn't until 1960    
    when the family started

93.text:
focusing on dairy         
      that the beef cattle

96.text:
and the pigs were weaned     
   out and the milking parlor

100.text:
Here's their story of      
     how that parlor got

104.text:
- My grandfather,        
       he took a big step

106.text:
and put a milking         
      parlor in, in 1969,

109.text: and redid the barn to fit that.

112.text:
He just enjoyed the        
     cows more than swine.

115.text:
They had some swine         
    when my dad was little,

117.text:
But he really didn't      
      care for the hogs.

119.text:
That's when we really        
   started focusing on dairy

121.text:
and making that their main   
   part of the operation.

126.text: My dad redid the parlor in 1995.

130.text:
He put new equipment       
     in and made it larger.

132.text:
We took automatic take-offs    
 so that the parlor could sense

136.text: when each cow was done milking.

138.text:
It was less watching      
      the flow of the milk

140.text: to try to take it off.

142.text:
So the parlor took       
       care of itself.

144.text: Each unit had its own sensor.

146.text:
That's better for the      
     cows' udder health.

150.text:
- [Laura Kay] But what      
    does an automated system

153.text:
- What it is, it's       
       a robotic milker.

155.text:
It preps the udder,        
     stimulates the udder,

158.text:
disinfects the             
     udder, gets it clean.

160.text:
Then it attaches and         
   collects the milk for us.

162.text:
So we aren't moving them    
    around like we used to.

165.text:
When we were in the parlor,   
  we would bring the cows

167.text: to the parlor three times a day.

170.text:
Now the cow goes to the       
  robot whenever she pleases.

173.text:
She's not milked every     
     single time she goes

175.text:
to the robot, and         
      sometimes some cows

177.text:
don't go to the robot      
     as much as we'd like

179.text:
so we bring them           
     there and helping them

181.text:
or pushing them pretty     
     much into the robot

184.text: so they get used to it.

187.text:
Five years ago we installed   
  an automatic calf feeder.

192.text:
Our cows that weren't       
    on the automatic feeder,

194.text:
they were more stubborn to    
  go into the robot at first.

198.text:
But it seemed like these     
   younger ones they remember

200.text:
from being a calf that      
    they got fed in a stall.

203.text:
Well now they're in a       
    stall, it's just larger.

205.text:
Other than the first milking   
 which when we help the robot,

208.text:
we do not have to touch a      
 cow when it comes to milking.

215.text:
It's just way             
      better for the cow.

216.text:
Also, it's better          
     for their production.

219.text:
We get more production out    
  of these cows because of it.

221.text:
- [Laura Kay] So what does   
   this mean for an average

227.text:
- Each cow has an             
  electronic tag on the collar

229.text:
on its neck and that      
      tag has a pedometer.

233.text:
So if her activity goes     
    down it will flag it

237.text:
Then also it counts       
      her rumination,

240.text:
which is how many minutes    
   a day she's eating

243.text:
So if she has a ruminating     
 average of 450 minutes a day,

246.text:
and one day she goes down    
   to 200, it will flag it

249.text:
and we can go and        
       check the cow out.

252.text:
It usually will show us she's  
 sick before she will show

255.text: visual signs of her being sick.

258.text:
We catch things quicker, and  
  the sicknesses don't take

260.text:
as large as a toll as they   
   would if we would have

262.text:
probably waited another      
   day before we can actually

265.text:
visually see that her ears   
   are down or she puffing.

268.text:
Before we can visually     
     see a sickness

271.text:
the robot and the           
    computer find it for us.

274.text:
From this system we went to     
five full-time employees to two.

278.text:
We cut down on our labor    
    force dramatically,

284.text:
What we really did is      
     we took the three jobs

285.text:
that we took away, the      
    money that we were using

287.text:
to pay them is now going     
   to make the loan payments

more automated than

296.text:
out of the future, it doesn't

can just sit back and let

my father's always really

and always trying to

We've always tried to stay

and try to keep up with         
industry and not dragged behind.

320.text:
I always looks for new       
   ways to be more productive

A lot of people say

326.text:
No, the only thing that a

It gives them a treat,

332.text:
the rest of their

335.text:
We're still here all      
      the time, it seems.
